post_info.post_title: It's Springtime and gas is $2.85/gallon for Premium

Coyote
You would hate California (besides for the obvious reasons ;) ). Gas is $3.49 /gallon for regular unleaded.
JPSartre12

You would hate California (besides for the obvious reasons ;) ). Gas is $3.49 /gallon for regular unleaded.

 
 Not only that but emission testing and 91Octane max.:xcensored
Coyote

Hey, yeah! Since I moved here, I haven't seen any 92 octane. I hadn't really noticed before!
 
 The emissions thing is a pain. Fortunately, the county I live in only requires you to get your car smogged when you sell it to someone else. Once it's smogged, you can rip all that smog gear off. If you never sell your car, you never have to worry about it again.
 
 Down in L.A., you have to get your car smogged once a year, no matter what. They put it on a dyno machine, so getting your car smogged costs about 100 bucks or more.
 
 I used to live in MI myself. You have fewer blatantly stupid rules than CA has, I'll admit.
Master_Shake
I just spent over $28 to fill up my Accord. What a load of ####.
E Mutz

I just love the phrase "get smogged." Delightful! "I went into town and got smogged!" I love it!
 
 I paid $2.68/g this Sunday at the big box store. I drive a 12 year old Saturn so I won't be seeing JP at the track anytime soon. It cost $29.00 to fill up the Wife's station wagon. I am cheap by nature so high gas hurts my constitution. Fortunately, I stashed a bunch of cans of $2.01 gas a few months back. I started doing this after Katrina. I am like a squirrel now: I have gas cans stashed in the garage, under the deck, in the hollow of a tree...
 
 I would bike to work if only the city planners would build a road with more than two inches between the white line and the ditch o' doom. My to-do list does not include serving as a hood ornament for a Lexus.
 
 My monthly gas budget is $200.00 for my wife and I. How does that compare to y'all?
 
 "Yeah you can drive into Atlanta if you don't mind getting smogged!"

 I spend ~$120/month in the warm months feeding my beast, another $80-100/month on my daily driver and my wife spends God knows how much, but she drives a lot, too. If I feel cheap and want to slum, I have a 95 Grand Am with a good stereo that I can drive instead of my Camaro or either of our two Chrysler T&C minivans. (We're parking-challenged at my house.) 
 
 As for seeing me at the track, I'm mostly relegated to being in pit crews now. Without a tow vehicle, taking my car to the track has become a PITA, so I'm lending my trailer to my son's buddy and helping crew for him. My son will also be driving someone else's car this summer, so I'll be busy with that as well. Should be a blast. My son'll be driving a car that spends more time vertical than it does horizontal so far. They need to tame the suspension before they wear out the back bumper. 
 http://www.lsffa.com/images/pics/cleanundercarriage.jpg
JPSartre12

I pay close to $ 7,- per gallon here in Holland. A full tank of gas costs me over $ 75,-.
 
 Doesn't that make you guys feel better? ;)

 
 Nah, we pay $11/gallon for C16 racing fuel. :)
daewoo

My monthly gas budget is $200.00 for my wife and I. How does that compare to y'all?

 
 We spend around $400 per month on fuel. 
 
 I have an F-450, and S class, and the wife drives an XK. We also have a minivan that does not get used very often. I have various toy cars as well, but most of them will not run off pump gas, so they have always been expensive to play with.
 
 On the up side, the expensive gas is helping drive down the price of rural real estate. The people who have the place on the other side of the section from me are trying to get it sold so they can move because between the two of them they drive 120 miles per day just going to and from work. The problem is that people are not exactly lining up to move into it for the same reason that they want out....new folks don't want the commute at $3 per gallon (local price) either.
 
 I suppose that if they had any brains (the current people) they would realize that MAYBE, just MAYBE getting rid of their gas sucking suburbans and getting something that is a little more fuel efficient would help mitigate the costs. Instead they will sell their house cheap and move their gas guzzlers to town. I figure I will let them sweat it out for another month or two and then get an agent to make an anonymous offer on the property, which they will accept, and I can knock down their hosue and put in a nice pond there. Ever since I moved here I have wanted to own the whole section and they are the last holdouts.

And....I love the F450. Did you get the turbocharged diesel and the leather interior? 

 
 I think the turbo diesel is standard if you want the diesel (I don't recall seeing a non turbo option). I went with the vinyl interior. I use it mostly to haul a horse trailer and to drag my skid steer around and to drive around in the hills. I shudder to think what a leather interior would look like by now. The Vinyl holds up pretty well and is easier to clean. 
 
 The sales guy tried REALLY hard to talk me into the leather since they had one on the lot that was more or less what I wanted but with leather. It was white, though, and I wanted red, so I told him that I would not take that one even if they threw in the leather for free.

 That's a bargain. Regular here is $3.24, premium is $3.45 emoticon_wow
daewoo

That's a bargain. Regular here is $3.24, premium is $3.45 emoticon_wow

 
 We were at $3.19 on monday. $3.25 today. 
 
 Anybody care to guess where prices will end up as the summer season peaks? I think that $4 is well within the realm of possibilities.
Waxy

We're up to $1.15/L (~$4.60/gal) here for regular, $1.25/L ($5/gal) for premium. It'll likely peak at around $1.25/L for regular right in time for the July long weekend, and then slowly wind down to between $1-1.10/L by fall.
 
 The funny thing is, gas prices have gone up $0.25/L in the last month and there hasn't really been any public outcry about it. Last year when gas prices cracked the $1/L barrier for the first time you'd swear that a law was decried that everyone must forfeit their first born.
 
 I know it probably really affects some people, but myself, I just go about my business. It doesn't really affect my driving habits or plans at all. My wife and I still drive downtown to work everyday, and I'm still loading up the V10 truck, 5th wheel and a couple dirt bikes and heading out to the ranch 3.5 hours away for the long weekend. 
 
 I might ride my shiny new KTM to work a little more often, but that's got nothing to do with gas prices. :p
 
 Waxy
gamehuis

We were at $3.19 on monday. $3.25 today. 
 
 Anybody care to guess where prices will end up as the summer season peaks? I think that $4 is well within the realm of possibilities.

 I've got a question about the whole "summer driving season". 
 Why is it that people in the US drive more in the summer? I mean, it would stand to reason that since the weather is better in the summer, people would drive less because they can just walk or ride a bicycle as opposed to the winter where peoples butts freeze off and walking or riding a bicycle is not a option.
 I myself drive less in the summer for that very reason and I know that most people in Holland act the same way.
 So why is it so different in the US?
 
 Oh and BTW, gasoline is close to $7,50 per gallon over here now. :p
E Mutz
My guess is that the summer is when folks drive to the beach, the mountains, or to Florida to see the Giant Rat. One cannot readily walk from Grabass Ohio to Crabgrass Kentucky.

 In my case, summer is drag racing season. We load the race car on the trailer and drive to races that are often hundreds of miles from my home. I also drive from Michigan to other states to visit relatives, sit on the beach, fly rockets and other seasonal activities. 
 Pulling a 7000# car and trailer on foot isn't an option. :)
Waxy

Pulling a 7000# car and trailer on foot isn't an option. :)

 
 Does your drag car weigh 7000#?! Is that car and trailer? What does the car weigh?
 
 That's WAY more than I would have thought. Is there weight limits?
 
 As for the "summer driving season", yeah, it's vacation time. Most people pack up and travel somewhere. I think where most "Europeans" get lost on this is in the sheer size of the USA or Canada. You can drive across Great Britain in 3-4 hours, it takes 7-8 hours to drive from where I live to where my parents live, and that's not considered a real long drive.
 
 Waxy

You can drive across Great Britain in 3-4 hours, it takes 7-8 hours to drive from where I live to where my parents live, and that's not considered a real long drive.

jim's trucking

Accounting for inflation, what would the price of gasoline have to get to to equal the price of gasoline in 1981, when it reached an all time high?
 
 I've heard something like $3.98.
gamehuis

Accounting for inflation, what would the price of gasoline have to get to to equal the price of gasoline in 1981, when it reached an all time high?
 
 I've heard something like $3.98.

 Adjusted for inflation the record gasoline price of $1.42 in 1981 would be equal to $3.20 - $3.35 today, depending on what inflation numbers one uses.
 So basically, in some areas in the US, the 1981 record has already been broken.
 
 Please note that I've used official government inflation numbers. If I used the 'real' inflation numbers then gasoline would have to hit $10,- or more to break the record.
